Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: And pouder marchaunt tart and gallyngale
Wel coude he knowe a drauȝt of londoıı̄un ale
He coude roste and sethe ⁊and boyle ⁊and friȝe
Make mortrews and well bake a pie
But gret harm was it / as þoute me
For on his shene amormal had he
For blankmanger madhe with the beste
¶ A shipman was ther wonnynge fer bi west
For ouȝt I wot he was of Der Dertemouthe
He rod vp on arounci as he couthe
In a goune of faleynge to þe kne
And a dagger hangid bi a lace had he
A boute his vndir his arme adoun
The hote somer had mad his visage broun
And certeinli he was a good felawe
Ful many a drauȝt of wyn hadde he drawe
Fro burdeux ward / while the chapman slepe
Off nyce conscience took he no kepe
For yef that he fauȝte and hadde the hiȝer hand
By water he sente hem home into eủer/rey land
But of his craftes to rekene wel the tides
His stremes and his daungeres him besides
His harborwe and his mone and his lodemanage
Thernas non suche fro hulle to Cartage
Hardi he was and wise I vndirtake
With manye atempest hadde his berd be shake
He knew the hauens as þey were
Fro Gotlond to þe cape of fene stere
And eủer/rey Crike in britaigne ⁊and in spayne
Hys barge i cleped is mawdaleyne
¶ With vs ther was a dottour of fisik
In al this world was non hym lyk
To speke of phisik or of surgerie
For he was gronded in astronomie
He kepte his pacient a ful gret del
In houris bi his magic naturel
Well coude he of fortune ascendent
Off his ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of eueri maladie
Were it of hote or cold or moist or drye
And where hit engendred or of what humour
He was a werry ꝑper/parfite practisour
The cause i knowe and of the cause þᵉ rote
Anon he gaff þe sik man his bote
Wel redy he hadde his apoticaries
To sende his dragges and his lituaries
For eủer/rey of hym mad othir for to wynne
Hir frenship was not new to begynne
Wel knew he the old Esculapius
And discorⁱdes and ek Rufus
Old ypocras haley and galyen
Serapioıı̄un Razis and auycen
Auerois damascien and Constantyn
Bernard catisden and Gilbertyn
Of his diot mesurabel was he
For hit was no suꝑper/parfluite
But of gret norisshinge and digestible
His studie was but litil on the bible
In sang ueyn and peers clad was he al
wᵗith taffata and wᵗith sendal
d ȝet he was but esy of dispense
e kepte þᵗat he wan in pestelence
or gold in phesik is acordia
Therfore he loued gold in special
¶ A good wyf ther was biside Bathe
But she was sumdel deeff and that was schaþᵉ
Off cloth makynge she had suche haunt
She passed hem of ypris and of gaunt
In all that parsh wiff was ther nōmn
That to the offeringe bifore hir shuld gōmn
And ief ther dide serteyn so wroth was she
That she was out of all Charite
Hir couer cheues ful fyne were of ground
I dorste swere they were worth pound
That on sonday were vp on hir hed
Hir hosen weren of scarlet red
Full streite ydrawe and shoos ful moist ⁊and newe
Bold was hir face and faire and red of hewe
She was a worthy woman all hir lyue
Husbondes att chirche dor she had fyue
With outen othir compaigne in youthe
But þer of nedeth not to speke as nowthe
And thries hadde she be at Ierusalem
She hadde passed many a stronge strem
At Rome she hadde ben and at boloigne
In Galeis at seynt Iame and at coloigne
She couthe meche of wanderynge by þᵉ way
Gattouthed she was soth for to say
Vp on an amblere esili she satt
Weympled wel and on hir hed an hatt
As brod as ony bokeler or a targe
A foot mantil aboute hir hepes large
And on her heles apeyre spures sharpe
In felawschippe wel couthe she langage ⁊and carpe
Off Remedies of loue she couthe perchaunce
For she couthe of þe art the old daunce
¶ Agood man was ther of religioıı̄un
And was a poure ꝑper/parson of a toune
But riche he was of holy thouȝt ⁊and werk
He was also alerned man a Clerk
That Cristes gospel trewly dede preche
Hys parisshens deuoutely wolde he teche
Benigne he was and woundir diligent
In aduersite also full pacient
And so was he preued many sithes
Ful loth was hym to cursse for his tithes
But rathir wold he ȝeue out of doute
Vn to his pore parisshens aboute
Off his offerynge and ek of his substaunce
He couthe in litil thyng haue suffisaunce
Wide was his parssh and houses ferre a sondre
But he sparet not for rayn ne thondre
In sikenesse ne in mishiff to visite
The ferrest in his parsh miche ne lite
Vp on his feet and in his hond a staff
This noble ensaumple to his sheep he ȝaff
That firste he wrouȝte and afterward he tawȝte
Out of the gospell he tho wordis rauȝte
And ek this figure he added mor ther to
That if gold ruste what shal Iren do
For ief a preest be foul on whom we truste
No woundir is thouȝ alewed man ruste
And shame it is if þe prest take kepe
A shetene shepherde ⁊and a clene sheepe
Wel auȝt a prest ensaumple for to yeue
Bi his clennesse how his sheep shuld leue
He ne set not his benefice to hire
Ne lett not his sheep acombred in þᵉ mire
Ne ranne not to londoıı̄un to seynt Poules
To geten hym a chauntrie for soules
Or with a bretherhed to be wiþ holde
But dwelte at hom and kepte wel his folde
So that no wolff make it not miscarie
He was a shepherde and not amercynarie
And thouȝh he holy were ⁊and vertuous
He was not to sinful men to dispitous
Ne of his speche daungerous ne deigne
But in his techynge discret and benigne
To drawe folk to heuēm by faiernesse
Bi good ensaunple that was his besinesse
But it were ony ꝑper/parsone obstinat
What so he were of high or lowe estat
Hym wolde he snybbe sharpely for þᵉ nons
A bettir prest y trowe that nowher non is
He waited after no pompe ne reuerence
Ne maked hym a spiced conscience
But cⁱstes lore and his aposteles twelue
He taughte / but firste he folwed it hymselue
¶ Wiþ hy þer was aplow man þᵗat was his brothyr
That had i lad of donge ful many a fothir
Atrewe swynker and a good was he
Leuynge in pees and in parfit charite
God loued he best with all his herte
At all tymes þow he gamed or smerte
And than his neigh bore riȝt as hym selue
He wolde thressche an þer to dike and delue
For cⁱstes sake to eueri pore wight
With outen hire if it lay in his migh
His tithes payed he ful fayre and wel
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke and catel
In a tabard he rede vp on a mere
¶ Ther was also a Reue and a millere
A sompnor and a pardoner also
Amaunciple and my self ther were no mo
The millere was astout carl for þᵉ nones
Ful bigge he was of braıı̄une and bones
That preued well oueral ther he cam
At wrestelynge he wolde haue a wey þᵉ ram
He was short shuldred a ꝓpropre þik knarre
Ther was no dore that he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it with arynnynge ayens his heed
His berd as ony sowe or fox was red
And therto brod as it were a spade
Vp on his coppe riȝt of his nose he hade
A werte / and ther on stood a tuft of heres
Red as the bresteles of a sowes ers
His nosethrillis blak were and wyde
A swerd and a bokeler he bare bi his side
His mouth as large was as a gret forneys
He was a gre Iangelere and a goliardeys
And that was most of synne and of harlotrie
Wel coude he stele corn and ek tolle thrie
And ȝett he hadde a thombe of gold ꝑper/parde
A whit cote and a blew hod wered he
A bagge pipe well couthe he Blowe ⁊and soun
And ther with he brouȝte vs out of toune
A Gentil maunciple ther was of þe temple
Off wheche achatours me myȝt take ensaumple
For to be wis in beynge of vetaile
For whethir he payde or tok bitayle
Alwey he awayted to his achate
That he was afore and in good estate
Now is nat this a ful fayre grace
That suche alewed mans witte shal pace
The wysdom of an heep of lered men
Of maistres had he more thanēm thries ten
That were of lawe expert an curious
Off wheche ther weren a dozen in þᵗat hous
Worthi to be stewardes of rente and lond
With ony lord that is in Ingelond
To make hym leue by his ꝓpropre gode
In hounore detteles but if he were wode
Or lyue as scarcely he can desire
And able for to helpe all ashire
In ony caas that myȝt falle or happe
And ȝett þis maunciple sett her alder cappe
This Reue was a sclendir colerik man
His berd was shaue as nyȝe as euer he can
His here was bi his eres ful round I shorn
His toppe was dokked like a prest biforn
Ful long were his legges and ful lene
Lik a staff þer was no calf sene
Wel couthe he kepe a gerner and a bynne
Ther was non auditour þat couthe on hym wyne
Wel knewe he bi þe drowȝte and bi þᵉ rayn
The ȝildīmgge of his seed and of his greyne
His lordis sheep his neet and his dayrie
His swyn his hors his stoor and his pultrie
Was holi in his Reues gouernyge
And bi the couenaunt þe rekenynge
Sith that his lord was twynti ȝeres of age
Ther couthe noman hym brynge in arerage
Ther was no baile ne herde ne othir hyne
That he ne knewe his sliȝt ne his couyne
They were agast of hym as of the deeth
His wonnynge was full fayre vp on an heth
With grene trees shadwe was hys place
He couthe wel better thanne his lord purchace
Ful riche he was astored priuili
His lord he coude plese subtely
To yeue and lene of his owne good
And haue a thank and ek a cote and an hood
In youthe he hadde lerned a gode myster
He was a ful good write a Carpenter
This Reue was vp on a wel good stoot
That was apomli gray and hiȝt scot
A longe surcote of peers vp on he he hadde
And bi his siþe he bare a rusty blade
Off northfolke was this Reue of wheche I telle
Beside a toune men clepe baldiswelle
Tucked he was as affrere aboute
And euer he rod þe henderest of oure route
¶ A sompnoure was þer with vs in þat place
That hadde ared Cherubynnes face
For sauceflem he was wiþ eyen narwe
As hote he was and as lecherous as is asparwe
With scaled browes blake and pillid berde
Of his visage Childeren were a ferd
Ther nas quiksiluer litarge ne brimston
Boras ceruce ne oile of tarter non
Ne oynement þat wolde clense orbite
That him myȝt helpe of his whelkis white
Ne of þᵉ knobbes sittynge on his chekes
Wel loued he garlik oynoıı̄uns ⁊and eke likes
And for to drinke stronge wyn red as blood
Thanne wolde he speke and crie as he were wod
And whanne that he wel dronken had þᵉ wyne
That wolde he speke no word but latyne
A fewe termes he hadde two or three
That he hadde lerned out of sum decre
No woundir is for he it herde alday
And ek ye knowe wel þᵗat a Iay
Can clepe watte as wel as can þᵉ pope
But who so coude him in oþir thing grope
Thane had he spent all his philosophie
Ay questio que iuris wlde he crie
He was agentil harlot and a kynde
A betir felawe shuld men nowher fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A good felawe to haue his concubyne
Atwelue month and excuse him att fulle
Ful pⁱriuili afinche cowþe he pulle
And if he fond owher a good felawe
He wolde techen hem to haue non awe
In suche caas off þᵉ erchedekens curs
But if mannes sowle were in his purs
For in his purs he shall pounyshed be
Purs is þe erchedekens helle seide he
But well ywot he lied riȝt in dede
Off curssynge ouȝte eủer/rey man to drede
For curssynge woll sle riȝt as a soylynge sauyþ
And also were him of a significauit
In daunger hadde he att his owne wille
The yonge gerles of his diocise loudeor still
And knewe hir conseill and was all hir red
A garlond had he set vp on his hed
As gret as it were vp on an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he mad him of a cake
¶ With hem þer was agentil ꝑper/pardoner
Off rouncivale his frend and his comper
That streiȝt was come from þe court of rome
Well loude he song com hedir loue to me
This sompnor bar to hym a stiff burdoıı̄un
Was neuer tromppe half of so gret a soun
This ꝑper/pardoner hadde heer as ȝelwe as wax
But smoþe it hyng as doth astreke of flax
Bi vnces hynge his lokkis þᵗat he hadde
And ther with he his shulders ouerspradde
But thynne it lay bi culpoıı̄uns bi on ⁊and on
But hode for Iolite wered he non
For it was trusset vp in his wallette
Hit semed he rode all of þᵉ newe Iette
Disheuele saue his cappe he rod all bare
Suche glarynge yen had he as an hare
A vernicle hadde he sewed vp on his cappe
His walet lay be fore him in his lappe
Brett ful of ꝑper/pardoıı̄un come from rome all hote
A voys he hadde as small as hath a gote
No berde hadde he ne neuer shuld haue
As smothe it was as it were late ishaue
I trowe he were a gildinge or a mare
But of his craft fro Berewik in to ware
Ne was þer suche an othir ꝑper/par donere
For in his male he bare apilwe bere
Wheche he seide þat was our ladi vaile
He seide he hadde agobbet of asayle
That seynt petʳ hadde whanne he wente
Vp on þe see til oure lord ihıı̄un crist him hente
He hadde a cros of laton ful of stones
And in a glas he hadde pigges bones
But wiþ these relekis whanne he fond
A poure ꝑper/parson dwellynge vp on lond
Vp on day he gat more monye
Thanne þeꝑper/parson gate in monthis tweye
And þus wiþ feyned flaterie and Iapes
He made þe ꝑper/parsou and þe peple his apes
But truly for to tellen att laste
He was in chirche anoble ecclesiaste
Wel coude he rede apistil or a stori
But alderbest he song an offertori
For wel he wiste whane þat song was songe
He moste preche and wel enfile his tonge
To wynne siluer as he wel coude
Ther fore he song þe merilier and loude
¶ Now haue I soteli told yow in a clause
The estate þe araye þe noumbre and þe cause
Whi þat assembled was þis compaignye
Atte southwerk att þis gentil hostelerie
That hiȝtte þe tabbard biside þe belle
But now is tyme for yow to telle
How þat we bare vs þat firste nyȝt
Whanne we were in þat osterie a liȝt
And after wil I telle of oure viage
And all þe remenaunt of oure pilgrimage
But first I prey Iow of youre curtesie
That ȝe ne rette it not in velonye
Thow I pleynly speke of þe matere
To telle yow her wordis and her chere
Ne þowȝ I speke her wordis properly
For þis knowe ȝe as wel as I
Who so shal telle atale aftir aman
He moste reherse as nigh as euer he can
Eueri word yef it be in your charge
Al speke he neuer so rudely noþur so large
Or ell he moste telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne þinges or feynde wordis newe
He may not spare þowȝ he were his broþur
He moste as wel seye oo word as an othur
Crist spak hym self full brode in holy writt
And wel ȝe wote no velonie is hit
Eke plato seith who so can him rede
The wordes mote be cosen to þᵉ dede
Also y prey iow forȝeue it me
Al haue y not set folk in her degree
Here in þis tale as þei shuld stonde
Mi witte is short ȝe may wel vndirstonde
¶ Gret chere mad oure ost vs eủer/reychone
And to þe soper he sette vs anone
He serued vs wel and faire wᵗith þᵉ beste
Stronge was þe wyne ⁊and wel to drinke vs leste
A semeli man was oure ost with alle
For to ben a Marchall in an halle
A large man he was with yen stepe
A fairer burgeys was not in chepe
Bold of his speche wis and wil y tauȝt
And of manhod him wanted nauȝt
Ek þer to he was ameri man
And after soper pleyen he began
And spak of merþe among oþer þinges
Whanne he hadde mad our rekenynges
And seide þus now lordynges trewly
Ye ben to me ryȝt welcome hertely
For bi my trouþe if þat I shal not lie
I siȝe not this ȝer so merie a compaignie
Attones / in þis herborwe as is now
Fayn wolde y do yow mirthe wiste y how
And of a merþe I am ryȝt wel beþought
To do yow ese and it schall coste you nouȝt
Ye gon to Caunturbury god yow spede
The blisful martir quyte yow your mede
And well y wot as ye gon by þᵉ wey
Ye shapen yow to talen and to pley
For treuly comfort ne merþe is nōmn
To ryde by þe wey as dōmm as a ston
And þerfore wil I make yow disport
As I sede arst / And do yow some comfort
And yf yow likith all bi on assent
For to stonden att my Iugement
And for to werken as y sha yow seye
To morwe whan ye ryden bi þᵉ weye
Now bi my faders soule that is ded
But ye meri be y will yeue you myn hed
Holde vp your honde with outen more speche
Oure conseill was not longe for to seche
It semed not vs to make it uise
And graunted þer to wᵗith owten more avise
And bad hym seye his ver dit as him leste
Lordyng9 quod he harkenyþ for þᵉ beste
But take it not in I prey yow in disdayn
This is þe poynt to speke it short and playn
That eueri of yow to shorten wᵗith his weye
In his viage shal telle tales tweye
To canturbery ward I mene it so
And homward shal tellen oþer two
Off auentures þat whilome haue hym befalle
And whiche of him þat berith him best off alle
That is to seyn þat tellith in þis caas
Tales of best sentence and most solas
Shal haue a sopper at oure alþer coste
In this place here sittynge bi þis poste
Whanne þat we come ageyn fro caıı̄unturbery
And for to make yow the more mery
I wil my silf goodly with yow ryde
Riȝt at myn owne cost and be youre gide
And who so wil my Iugement wiþ seye
Shal paye al þat we spende bi þe weye
And ȝf ie wouche sauf þat it be so
Telle me anone with outen wordis mo
And y will erly shape þerfore
These þynges were graunted and oure oþesswore
Wiþ glad herte and prayen him also
That he wouchesauf for to do so
And þat he wolde Be oure gouernoure
And of oure tales Iuge and reportoure
And sette a soper at a certeyn pris
And we wolde reuled be atte his deuys
In hiȝ an lowe and þus by bi on assent
We ben acordet to his Iugement
And þer vp on þe wyne was fett anon
We dronken and to reste wente eủer/reychon
Wiþ outen ony lenger tarynge
Amorwe whanne þᵉ day ganne sprynge
Vp ros oure ost and was oure alder cok
And gaderde vs to geder on a flok
And forþ we reden alitil mor þe paas
Vn to þᵉ waterynge of Seynt Thomas
And þer oure ost be gan his hors to areste
And seide lordes harkeneþ if ie leste
Ȝe wot youre forward and I ȝow it recorde
Yeff euesonge and morwe songe acorde
Lat se now who shal telle þe firste tale
As euer I mot drynke wyne or ale
Who so be rebel to my Iugement
Shalle paye for all þat bi þe weye is spent
Now drawe we cutte or þat we ferþ̉er/re twynne
He þat hath þe shortest shal begynne
Sir knyȝt quod he my maister and my lord
Now drawith cutte for þat is myn acord
Comyþ ner quod he my lady prioresse
And lat be ȝe sir clerk your shamefastnesse
Ne studieth not ley on hond euery man
To drawe anon euery man bigan
And shortli forto tellen as it was
Were it bi auenture or scort or caas
The soþe it is þe kut fel to þe knyȝt

(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool

div.l: (base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due

div.l: (base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord

div.l: (base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
Whanne the knyȝt had his tale told

And namely the gentell eủer/reychone
Oure ooste lowȝ and swore so mote y gone
This goth wel vnbokeled is þe male

For trewly this game is well bigonne
Now telle ye ʆser/sire monke yef ye conne The ꝓprologꝭes of þᵉ Mellere
Somwhat to quyte with the knyȝtes tale
The Miller that for dronke was al pale
So that vnethe vp on his hors he sat
He wolde auale nothur hood ne hat

And swore bi armes bi blode and bi bones
I can a nobil tale for þe nones

But first I make a protestacioıı̄un

Bothe of A wriȝte and of his wyf
How a clerk sette þe wryȝtes cappe
The carpenter answerde stinte þy clappe
Late be thy lewed dronken harlotrie
Hit is a synne and eke g a gret folie
To appeiren ony man or to defame
And eke to brynge in suche name
Thow maiste I now of oþur thynges seyen
This dronken meller spak ful sone ageyne
And seide gode brothur osewolde
Who so hath no wyf is no cokowolde
But y seye not therfor that þou art on
There bene ful gode wyues manyon
Whi art thow angry with my tale now
I haue a wyf ꝑper/parde as wel as thow
Ȝet wolde y not for alle the oxen in my plow

As demen of my self that y wer on

An husbond shal not be inquisitif

Off the remenaıı̄unt nydith not to enquer̉er/re
What shulde y seye more but þe miller̉er/re
He wolde for noman his wordis forbere
But telle his cherles tale in his maner̉er/re
Me forthenkith that y shall telle it her̉er/re
And therfore eủer/rey gentil wyȝt y praye

Of euel entent but for y mote reherce
Here tall alle be they bet̉er/re or wesse

And therfore who so liste not for to her̉er/re
Torne ouer þe leef and chise an othir tale
For ye shuld fynde y nowe boþᵉ grete ⁊and smale

Blame not me yef that ye chese amys

So was þe reue and eke oþur mo
And of harlotrye they tolde boþᵉ two
Auysith yow and put me out of blame
And eke men shall not make of ernest of game
Whilome ther was dwellynge in oxenford
A Riche gnuffe that gestis held to bord
And of his craft he was a carpenter
With hym ther was dwellynge apore scoler
Had lerned art but all his fantasie
Was torned to astrologie
And couthe a certeyn of conclusiones
To deme bi int̉er/rerogaciones
Yef that men asked of certeyn oures
Whethur men shuld haue drouȝte or ell showres The Millere
Or yef men shuld axe him what shuld falle
Off euery thyng men may not rekene alle
This clerk was cleped hende nycolas
Of derne loue he couthe and of solas
And ther to he was slyȝe and ful priue
And lik a mayde meke for to see
A Chaumbre had he in þat hostelerie
Al alone wiþ outen any compaignye
Ful fetisly diȝt with herbes swete
And he him self as he it were þe rote swete
Of licorice or of ony situale
His almageste with his bokes gret ⁊and smale

Hys augrym stones layn fayr a part
On shelues couched att his beddis hed

And al aboue ther lay agay sautrie
On wheche he made a nyȝt melodye
So swetely that al the Chaumbur ronge

And afir that he song þe kynges note
Wel ofte blissed was his mery throte
And thus þe suete clerc his tyme spente
Aftir his frendis fyndynge and his rente
This Carpenter hadde wedded a newe wif
Whiche that he loued more þane his lif
Of xviij ȝeres she was of age
Ielowse he was and kepte hir narwe in cage
For she was ȝong and wild and she was old
And demed him self be lik a cokewold
He knewe not catoıı̄un for his witte was rude
That bad men shuld wedde hir similitude
Men shuld wedde aftʳ hir estate
For youthe and elde bene ofte at bate
But sith he was falle in þe snare
He moste endur as othur folk her care
Full fayre was þys yonge wyff with alle

A seinte she wered barred all of silk
A barmecloth as white as ony mylk
Vp on her lende ful many agore
White was hir smok and browded al afore

Of cole blak silk with Inne and eke wᵗith oute
The tapes of þe white volipere

Full small y pulled were hir browes two
And tho were bent and blak as ony slo

Thanne is þe new pere on þe Ionette tree

And there hunge a purs bi hir girdil of lethur

In all this world to seke vp an doun

Full bryȝt was the shynynge of hir hewe
As in the tour the noble forged newe
But of hir song she was so loude and yerne

For ony lord to liggen in his bed
Or ȝit for ony gode ȝoman to wed
Now sire and eft ʆser/sire so bifel this caas
That on a daye this hende Nicolas The Millere
Fil with this ȝonge wif to rage and play
While that hir husbond was att Osenay
As clerkes ben ful subtel and ful queynte
And pruuli he cauȝt hir bi the quente

Nay there of care ye not ꝙquod nicolas

The wheche that was cleped absolon

The parissh clerc this Ioly absoloıı̄un The Millere

And whan eueri of hym hadd dronken his part
This nicholas his dore faste shette
And doıı̄unn the carpenter bi him he sette The Millere
And seide Iohn myn oste lieff and dere
Thou shalt vp on my trouthe swere me here
That to no wyȝt thou shalt this consell wrye
For it his cristes consell that y seye
And yef thow telle it man þou art forlore
For this vengeaunce shalt þou haue þerfor
That yef þou wrye me þou shalt be wood
Nay crist for bede it for his holy blod
Quod this seli man y am no labbe
And thow y seye hit y am not lieff to gabbe
Sey what þou wilt y shall it neuer telle
To child ne wyf bi him that haried helle
Now Iohn ꝙquod nicholas y wille not lye
I haue founden in myn astrologie
As y haue loked in þe mone bryȝt
That now on moneday next at quarter nyȝt
Shal falle a reyne and that so wilde and wode
That half so gret was neuer noyes flood
This world he seide in lesse þan in an our
Shall all be dreynte so hidous in þe shour
Thus shall mankynde drenche and lese her liff
This carpenter answerde allas my wyff
And shall she drenche allas myn Alison
For sorwe of this he fell almost doun
And seide is ther no remedie in this caas
Why ȝis for god ꝙquod hende nycholas
Yef thow wilt worke aftir lore and red
Thow maist not worke aftir þyn owne hed
For thus seith salamon þat was ful trewe
Werke all by consell and thou shalt not rewe
And yef thow werke wilt bigood conseill
I vndirtake with outen mast or saill
And ȝit shall y saue hir and þe and me
Hastow not herd how saued was noe
Whanne our lord hadde warned him bifor
That all þe world with water shuld be lor
Yis ꝙquod this carpenter ful ȝor ago
Hastow not herd ꝙquod nycholas also
The sorwe of noye with his felawshyppe
Or he myȝt gete his wiff to shippe
Him hadde be leuer y vndirtak
Att thilke tyme thanne all his wethres blake
That she had hir silf a ship alone
And therfor wost thow what is best to done
This axet haste and of an hasti thing
Men may not preche ne make tariynge
Anon go gete vs faste in to þis in
Aknedynge trowȝe or ell a kemelyn
For ecche of vs but loke that they be large
In whiche we mowe swymme as in a barge
And haue there Ine vetaile sufficient
But for a day fi on þe remenaunt
The water shal a slake and gon away
About prīmme vpon þe nexte day
But Robyn may not wete of this þy knaue
And eke thy mayde gille I may not saue
Axe not whi for thow thou axe me
I wille not telle goddis priuite
Hit sufficith but if thi wyttes madde
To haue a grette grace as noe hadde
Thy wif shall I well sauen out of doute
Go now thy wey and spede the her aboute
But whane thow hast for hir and þe and me
I geten vs this knedyng tobbes thre
Thanne shalt thou hangen in þy roff full hie
That noman of our puruyaunce aspie
And whanne thow hast don as y haue seid
And hast our vitayle fayr in him leid
And an ax to smite þe corde atwo
Whane that the water comyth that we may goo
And breke an hole an hiȝe vp on þe gable
Vn to þe gardeyn ward ouer þe stable
That we may passe freli on oure wey
Whane the gret shoure is gon a way
Thanne shalt thou swymme as meri I vndirtake
As doth the white doke aftir his drake The Millere
Thanne wille y clepe how Alisoıı̄un how Iohn
Be meri fro þe flod will passen anon
And thow wilt sayn hayle maistir nycholay
Gode morwe for y se þe well for it is day
And thanne shull we be lordes all our liff
Off al this world as noe and his wiff
But of o thyng y warne þe ful ryȝt
Be well auysed on þat ilke nyȝt
That we ben entred with Inne shippes bord
That non of vs ne speke neuer a word
Ne clepe ne crie but be in his pᵃyere
For it is goddes owne heste dere
Thi wyff and thow most hange ferre atwynne
For that bitwyx yow shall be no syne
Nomor in lokynge than shal in dede
This ordenaıı̄unce is seid go so god yow spede
To morwe at nyȝt whane þey be all aslepe
In to our knedynge tobbes woll we crepe
And sette ther abydynge goddis gᵃce
Go now thy wey I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger ʆser/sirmonyngge
Men seyn thus sende þe wise and seye nothynge
Thow art so wise it nedeth not þe to teche
Go saue our lyff and that y the beseche
This sely carpenter goth forth his way
Ful ofte he seide allas and welleway
And to his wif he told his priuite
And she was war and knewe it bet þan he
What all thys queynte cast was for to seye
But netheles she ferde as she wolde deye
And seyde alas go forth thy wey anon
Helpe vs to scape or we be ded echon
I am thy trewe verrey weddid wyff
Go dere spouse to helpe to saue our liff
Loo wheche a gret thyng is affeccioıı̄un
Men may dye of ymaginacion
Se depe may impressioıı̄un betake
This seli carpenter began for to quake
Him thinkith verily that he may see
Noees flood com walwynge as þe see
To drenche Alison his hony dere
He wepith and wailed and makith sori chere
He sikith with ful many sory swowȝ
And goth and getith him a knedyng trowȝ
And aftir a tubbe and a kemelyn
And priuily he sente hem vnto his in
And hinge hem in þe roff in priuite
With his owne handes he made ladderes iij
And clomben by þe ronges and staues
Ther to leten as men don for drede in caues
And him vitayled boþᵉ trowȝ and tubbe
With bred and chese and good ale in Iubbe
Suffysynge ryȝt y now as for o day
But or that he hadde mad al þat aray
He sente his knaue and eke his wenche also
Vp on his nedis to londoıı̄un for to go
And on þe monedaye whane it drowȝ to þᵉ nyȝt
But shette his dore with outen candil lyȝt
And dresshed all thyng as it shuld be
And shortly vp they clomen all thre
They setyn stille well a forlonge wey
Now pater noster seide nycolay
And clum ꝙquod Iohn and clum ꝙquod alisoıı̄un
This carpenter seyde his deuocioıı̄un
And stille he sitte and biddith his pᵃyere
Awaytynge on the reyn yef he it myȝt here
The ded slep for weri besinesse
Fil on this carpenter ryȝt as I gesse
Abut couerfewe tyme or litil more
For tᵃuayll of his gost he gronyth sore
And ofte he routhith for his hed myslay
Doun of þe laddere stalkith nycholay
And alison doun ful softe she spedde
With outen wordes mo they wente to bedde
There as þe carpenter was wont for to lie
There was the reule and the melodye The Millere
And thus lith alison and nicholas
And besynesse of merthe and in solas
Till the belles of lawdes gonne rynge
And freres in chauncel gonne synge
This parissh clerk this amerous absoloıı̄un
That is alwey for loue so woo be gon
Vp on the moneday was at Oseneye
With compaignye him to disporte and play
And asked vp on a caas a cloisterer
Full priuily aftyr Iohn the carpenter
And drow him apert out of þe chirche
And seide I not I saw him here not worche
Sith satirday that he hens went
For tymbre ther our abbot him sent
For he is wont for tymbre for to goo
And dwellynge at graunge a day or twoo
Or ell he is at his hous certeyn
Wher that he be I can not soþely seyn
This absolon ful Ioly was and lyȝt
And thouȝt now is tyme to wake all nyȝt
For sekyrly he saw him not sterynge
About his dore syn day began to sprynge
So mote y thriue y shall att cokkes crowe
Full priuily knokke at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe vp on his bowris wall
To alison wille y talken all
My louelongynge for ȝit y shall not misse
For att leste wey I shall hir kysse
Som maner comfort shall y haue ꝑper/parfay
My mouth hath iccheth al this longe day
That is a signe of kyssynge atte leste
All nyȝt me mette eke that I was at a feste
Therfore y wille slepe an hour or twey
And al þe nyȝt thanne wille I walke and pᵃy
Whanne the firste cokke had crowed anon
Vp sterte this Ioly louer absoloıı̄un
And him arayed gay att poynt deuys
But first he chewith greynes and licoris
To smelle swete or he had kempt his heer
Vnder his tonge a trewe loue he bere
For ther bi wende he for to haue bene gᵃcious
He rometh vn to þe Carpenters hous
And stille he stond vndir þe shot wyndowe
Vn to his breste it rauȝte it was so lowe
And softe he couched with a semy swoun
What do ȝe hony combe swete alison
My faire brid my swete synamome
A wakith lemman myn and spekith to me
Well litil thenk ye vp on my woo
That for your loue y swete as y go
No wounder is thouȝ y swilte or swete
I morne as doth þe lombe aftir þe tete
Iwis leman I haue suche a loue longynge
That lik a turtull trewe is my mornynge
I may not ete nomor thane a mayde
Goo fro the wyndowe ȝak fole she seide
As helpe me god it will not be come bame
I loue an othur or ell y wer to blame
Well bet thane the bi Ihıı̄un absoloıı̄un
Go forth thy wey or ell y will caste a ston
And lete me slepe atwynti deuelwey
Allas ꝙquod Absolon and wellaway
That treweloue was euer so well be sett
Thane kysse me sith it may be no bett
For Ihıı̄un loue and for the loue of me
Wilt thow thane go thy wey there with ꝙquod she
Ȝe certis lemman ꝙquod this absoloıı̄un
Thanne make þe redy ꝙquod she y come anon
This absolon doun sette him on hys knes
And seyde y a lord att all degres
For aftir this y hope ther comyth more
Lemman thi gᵃce and suete brid þy ore
The wyndow she vndoth an þat in haste
Haue do ꝙquod she come off and spede þe faste
Lest that our neyȝbores þe aspye
This absolon gan wepe his mouth full drye The Millere
Derke was the nyȝt as piche or ony cole
And att the wyndow she put out hir hole
And absolon hym fill no bat ne wers
But with his mouth he kyste hir naked ers
Full sauerly or he wer war of thys
A bak he sterte and thouȝt it was amys
For well he wiste a woman had no berd
He felte a rouȝ thinge and longe I hered
And seide fy allas what haue y do
Te he ꝙquod she and clapped the window to
And absolon goth forth a sori paas
A berd aberd ꝙquod hende nicholas
By goddis corps this goth faire ⁊and well
This sely absolon herde eueridell
And on his lippe for anger he gan bite
And to him sylf he seide y shall þe quyte
Who rubbith now how fretith now his lyppys
With dust with sond with straw wiþ chippes
But absolon that seide ful ofte allas
My sowle y be take to satanas
But me were leuer thanne all this world ꝙquod he
Off this dispite y wroken for to be
Allas ꝙquod he allas y ne hadde y ne blent
Hys hote loue was cold and all y queynt
For fro the tyme that he had kyst hir ers
Off ꝑper/paramours ne sette he not a kers
For he was helyd of his maladie
Full ofte ꝑper/paramours he ganne defie
And wepe as doth a child that is bete
A softe pas he wente ouer the strete
Vn to a smyth men cleped him daun Gerueys
That in his forge made plowȝ harneys
He sharpeth share and cultir bisily
Thus absoloıı̄un knokketh all esily
And seyde to gerueys an that anon
What who art thow it am y absoloıı̄un
What absolon what cristes owne tree
Why rise ȝe so rathe ey benedicite
What eylith yow some gay girle god it wote
Hath brouȝt you thus on þe veriote
By seynte note ye wote what y mene
This absolon ne rouȝte not a bene
Off all his pley no word agayn he gaff
He hadde mor tow on his distaff
Thene gerueys knew and seide frend so dere
The hote culter in thy chemeney her
As lene yt me y haue ther with to done
I will brynge it þe ageyn full sone
Gerues answerde certes wer it golde
Or in a poke nobles all vntold
Thow shuldist haue it as y am trew smyth
Ey certes foo what will ye do ther with
There of absoloıı̄un be as be may
I shall well tetelle to morwe a day
And cauȝte þe culter bi þe cold stele
Wel softe he gan out of þe dore stele
And wente vn to þe carpenters wall
He cowȝhed first and knoked þer with all
Vp on the wyndowe as he dede er
This alison answerde how is there
That knokyth so y warant it a theff
Way nay ꝙquod he god wot suete liff
I am absoloıı̄un thyn owne derlynge
Of gold ꝙquod he y haue brouȝt a rynge
My moder yaue it me so god me saue
Full fyn it is and þerto wel y gᵃue
This wol I yeue the yef thou me kysse
This nicholas was reson for to pysse
And thouȝt he wolde amende all þe Iape
He shuld kysse his ers or þat he scape
And vp the wyndow he dede hastly
And out his ers he put priuily
Ouer the buttok to þe þe haunche bon
And there with spak this clerc this absoloıı̄un
Speke swete brid y not wher thow art
This nycholas anon lete flee a fert The Millere
As grete as it had ben a thondyr dynt
That with þe stroke he was almost blynt
And he was redy with his Iron hote
And nycholas in þe ers he smot
And of goth the skynne an handbrede aboute
The hote cultr brende so his toute
And for þe smert he wende for to dye
As he wer wood for wo he gan to crie
Help water water help for godde herte
This carpenter out of his slomber sterte
And herde on crye water as he wer wood
And thouȝt allas now comyth noies flood
And sette him vp with outen wordes moo
And with an ax he smot þe corde atwo
And doun he goth he fond nothur to selle
No bred ne ale til he come to selle
Vp on the flore there on swowne he lay
Vp stirt hir Alisoıı̄un and nycholay
And cried out and herowe in þe strete
The neyȝebores boþe smale and grete
In ronnen for to gauren on this man
That on swoıı̄un lay boþe pale and wan
But for that fall brosten had his arm
And stonde he moste on his owne harm
For whanne he spak he was anon born doıı̄un
With hende nycholas and alison
They told eủer/rey man that he was wood
He was agast so of noes flood
Thurgh a fantasie of his vanyte
That he had bouȝt him knedynge tubbes þre
And had him hanged in þe rouff aboue
And that he preyed hem for goddes loue
To sittyn in þe roof ꝑper/par compaignye
The folk lowen att his fantasie
And to þe roof they kiken and þey gape
And turned all his ernyst vn to a Iape
For what so this carpenter ansuerde
It was for nouȝt noman his resoıı̄un herde
With grete othus he was so sworn adoıı̄un
That he was holden wood in al the toıı̄unn
For euery clerc anon held with othur
They seide the man was wood my lyue brothur
And euery man gan lawȝe at his striff
Thus swyued was the Carpenters wiff
For all his kepynge and hys Ielosye
And absoloıı̄un hath kyst hir nether ye
And nicholas is scalded in his toute
This tale is do and god saue alle þe route
(base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
(base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke

div.l: (base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke

div.l: (base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
(base) As piled as an Ape was his skulle
(base) He was a Market beter at the fulle
(base) Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
(base) That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
(base) A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
(base) And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
(base) His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
(base) A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
(base) The person of the toun hir fader was
(base) With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
(base) For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
(base) She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
(base) For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
(base) But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
(base) To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
(base) And she was proud and peert as is a pye
(base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
(base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
(base) That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
(base) A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
(base) Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
(base) Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
(base) In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
(base) With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
(base) With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
(base) But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
(base) The person of the toun for she was so feir
(base) In purpos was to maken hir his heir
(base) Bothe of his catel and his Mesuage
(base) And straunge he made it of hir mariage
(base) His purpos was to makyn hir his eire
(base) His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
(base) In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
(base) For holicherches good moot been despended
(base) On holicherches blood that is descended
(base) Ther fore he wolde his holy blood honoure
(base) Thogh that he holy chirche sholde deuoure
(base) Greet sokne hath this Miller out of doute
(base) With whete and malt of al the land aboute
(base) And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
(base) Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
(base) Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde
(base) And on a day it happed in a stounde
(base) Syk was this maunciple on a maladie
(base) Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
(base) For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn

Ief i be gilteles of this velonie
Mi socour be or elles moste I die
¶ Haue ȝe not seyn somtyme allas
Among aprees of him that hath be lad
Toward his deth where as him gete no grace
And suche a colour in his face hath had
Men might knowe his visage that was be stad
Among alle the faces in þat route
So stant Custaunce and lokith hir aboute
¶ Oquenes lyuynge in prosꝑper/parite
Duchesse and ladies eủer/reychon
Haue som Reuthe of hire aduersite
An Emꝑper/parours douȝtir stant alloıı̄un
She hath no wiȝt to whom to make hir mone
O blod Rial that standest in this drede
Fer be thi frendes att thi grete nede
¶ This Alla kyng hath suche compassioıı̄un
As gentil herte is ful of pite
That from his yen Ran þe water doun
Now hasteliche do fecche a book qd he
And yef this knyȝt woll swern how that she
This woman slowȝ / ȝit wol we us auise
Whom that we wolle that shall be our Iustice
¶ Abriton book y wreten with Euᵃngeles
Was fett and on this book he swore anon
She gilti was and in the menwhiles
An hand him smote vp on the nekke bon
That doun he fel at ones as a ston
And bothe his yen brosten out of his face Man of Lawe
Fro his constable as ye shal aftʳ here
¶ This letter spak the quene deliuered was
Off so horrible a fendeli Creatur
That noman in the castel so hardi was
That ony while durste þere Inne endur
The moder was an Elf bi auentur
I come bi charmes or bi sorcerie
And eueri man hatith hir compaignie
¶ Woo was the kyng whanne he the leter had seyn
But tonoman he tolde his wordes sore
But of his owne hond he wrot ageyn
Welcome the sonde of crist for euermore
To me that am now lerd in his lore
Lord welcome be thi lust and thi plesaunce
My lust y put alle in thin ordinaunce
¶ Kepe this Child albe it foul or fair
And eke my wif vn to myn hom comynge
Crist whan him list may sende me an Ayre
More agreable than this to my likynge
This letter he seleth priuili wepynge
Wheche to the messengere was takesone
And forth he goth there is nomore to done
¶ Omessenger fulfullid with drōmkenesse
Strong is thi breth thi lymes falteren ay
And thow biwreieste al thi sikernesse
Thi mynde is lorn thow Iangelest as a Iay
Thi face is torned in anew aray
Thi dronkenesse Reyneth in any route
There is no consel hid with outen doute
¶ O dongild Ine haue non Englissh digne
Vn to thi malice and thi Tirannye
And to þe fend therefore I þe resigne
Late him endite of thi traitorie
Fy mannyssh fy onay bi god I lie
Fy fendly spirit for y dar wel telle
Thowȝ thou here walke thi spirit is in helle
¶ This messenger comyth fro þe kyng ageyn
And att the kynges moders court he lyȝt
And she was of this messanger full fayn
And plesith him in al that euer she myȝte
He drank and wel his girdil vnder piȝt
He slepthe and fnorted in his gise
Al niȝt til the sonne gan rise
¶ Eft were his lres stolen eủer/reychone
And conterfeted lres in this wise
The kyng comaundeth his constable anon
Vp peyne of hangynge and hie Iuwise
That he neshuld suffre in no wyse
Custaunce wᵗithInne his reigne for to abide
Thre dayes and a quarter of atide
¶ But in the same shippe as he hir fond
Hir and hir yonge sone and all hir ger
He shuld put /// And crowde fro þe lond
And Charge hir that she neuer eft come þer
O my custaunce wel may thi gost haue fer
And slepynge in thi drēmm haue penaunce
Whanne dongilde casteth al this ordenaunce
¶ This messengere on morwe whāmne he woke
Vn to þe castel halt þe nexte way
And to þe constable he þe letter toke
And whanne he this pitous lre Isay
Wel ofte he seide allas and welaway
Lord crist qd he how may this world endur
So full of synne is many a creatur
¶ Almyȝti god if that it be thi wille
Sith that thow art ryȝtfull Iuge how may þis be
That thow wilt suffre Innocentes to spille
And wikked folk regnen in prosꝑper/parite
O gode Custaunce allas so woo ys me
That y moste be thy tormentour or dye
On shames deth ther is non othir weye
¶ Wepen both yonge and olde in that place
Whanne that the kyng þis cursed lre sente
And Custance with a dedly pale face
The iiij day toward the ship she wente
But natheles she toke it in good entent Man of Lawe
The wille of Crist and knelynge on the stronde
She seide lord ay wilcome be thi sonde
¶ He that me kepte fro the false blame
While y was in the lond amonges yow
He can me kepe fro harm and eke fro shame
In the salte see althowȝ y see not how
As stronge as euer he was he is ryȝt now
In him triste y and to his moder dere
That is to me my saile and eke my ster
¶ Hir litil Child lay wepynge in hir arm
And knelynge pitously to him she seide
Pees litil sone y woll do the non harm
With that hir couerchiff ouer hir hed she breide
And ouyr hir litil Childe she it leide
And in hir arm she lulleth it ful faste
And in to heuene her yen vp she kaste
¶ Moder qd she and briȝt maide marie
Soth is that thorwȝ wommannes eggement
Mankynde is lost and dampned ay to die
For whiche thi child was on crosse yrent
Thi blisful yen saw all his tornement
Thanne is there non comꝑper/parisoıı̄un bitwene
Thi woo // And Any woo þat man may sustene
¶ Thow saw thi sone yslayn before thi yen
And ȝit now leueth my litil sone ꝑper/parfay
But ladi briȝt to whom all woful crien
Thow glorie of womanhod thou faire may
Thou hauene of refute briȝt sterre of day
Rewe on my Child for thi gentilnesse
That Rewest on alle Reuful indistresse
¶ O litil Child allas what is thi gilt
That neuer wrouȝtest synne as ȝit ꝑper/parde
Whi wolle thin hard fader haue þe spilt
O merci dere constable qd she
As late my litil Child dwelle her with þe
And thow darst not saue blame
So kisse him ōmns in his name
¶ With that she loked bakward land
Fare wel husbond she seide routheles
And vp she rist and walketh doun to þe stronde
Toward the ship hir folwith all the prees
And euer she preieth hir child to holde his pees
And takith hir leue with an holi entent
She blessed hir and in to þe shippe she went
¶ Vitailed was the ship with outen drede
Habundanteli for hir ful longe space
And othur necessaries that shuld nede
She had ynow heried be goddes grace
For wynd and weder almiȝti god purchce
And bringe hir hom I can no better say
But in the see she driueth forth hir way
¶ Alla the kyng comyth sone hom aftʳ this
Vn to his castell of whiche y tolde
And axeth wher his wiff and his Child is
The Constable gan way abouȝte his herte alcode
And pleynli all the maner he him tolde
As y haue herd y can sey no betre
And shewed the kynge his seal and his letter
¶ And seide lord as ye comaunded me
Vp peyn of deth so haue y doıı̄un certein
This messengere tormented was til he
Muste biknowen to tellen plat and pleyn
Fro nyȝt to nyȝt in what place he hed leyn
And thus bi witt and subtil enquerynge
Imagyned was bi whom this harm gan sprynge
¶ This hond was knowe that this letter wrotte
And alle the venym of this cursed dede
But in what wise certeinli y not
The effect is this that alla out of drede
His moder slowȝ that men may pleynly rede
For that she traitour to hir legeaunce
Thus endeth olde donegild with mishaunce
¶ The sorwe that alla niȝt and day
Maketh for his wiff and his Child also
There is nothing that it telle may
But now wille I ageyn to custaunce goo Man of Lawe
That fletith in the see in peyne and woo
V ȝere and more as liked cristes sonde
Or that hir approched on to londe
¶ Vnder an hethen castel att laste
Off the whiche the name in my tixt y nefynde
Custaunce and eke hir child þe see vp caste
Almyȝti god that saued all mankynde
Haue on Custaunce ⁊and on hir Child some mynde
That fallen is in hethen hond eft sone
In poynt to spille as y shall telle ȝow sone
¶ Doun from the Castell there cometh many awyȝt
To gaweren on this ship and on Custaunce
But shortly from the castel on an anyȝt
The lordes steward god ȝeue him meshaunce
A theef that hath reneyd oure Creaunce
Com in to þe ship and seide he shulde
Hir lemman bem wherther she wolde or nolde
¶ Wo was this wrecched woman tho bigon
Hir child cried ⁊and she cried also pitousli
But blisful mari halp hir ryȝt anon
For with hir strongelynge wel and myȝtly
The theff fell ouer the bord al sodeinly
And in the se he dreinte for vengeaunce
And thus hath Crist vnwemmed kept Custaunce
¶ O Foul lust of lecherie lo thin ende
Nouȝt only that thou fayntest mannes mynde
But verrili thow wilt his bodi shende
The ende of thi werk or of thi luste blynde
Is compleynynge how many on may men fynde
That not for work some tyme but for entent
To doıı̄un this synne be slayn or y shent
¶ How may this weike woman haue the strengthe
Her to defende ageyn the renegat
O golias vnmesurable of length
How myȝt dauid make the so mate
So yong ⁊and of armur so desolat
How durste he loke vpon the dredfull face
Wel may men se it was but godde grace
¶ Who iaff Iudith corage or hardinesse
To slee Oliphernes in his tent
And to deliuer ouȝt of wrechednesse
The peple of god y sey for this entent
That ryȝt as god spirit and vigor sent
To hem that saued hem oute of misshaunce
So sent he myȝt and figor to Custaunce
¶ Forth goth hir ship thurwȝ the narwe mouthe
TurwTurwȝTurwȝ Iubalter and sept dryuynge ay
Somtyme west and somtyme north and southe
And somtyme Est fulmany a very way
Til cristes moder blessed be she ay
Hath shapen thourȝ hir endeles goodness
To make an ende of all hir heuynesse
¶ Now late stinte of custaıı̄unce but athrowe
But speke we of the Romayn Emꝑper/parour
That out of surrey hath by lres knowe
The slauȝtir of cristen folk and dishonour
Don to his douȝtir bi a fals traitour
I memenemene by the fals cursed sowdannesse
That att the feste lete sle more ⁊and lesse
¶ For whiche this Emꝑper/parour hath sent anon
His senatour with Riail ordinaunce
And othir lordes god wot many on
An surriens to taken hi vengeaunce
They brennen slen ⁊and bryngen hem to mysshaıı̄unce
Ful many a day but shortly this is the ende
Homward to Rome shapen hem to wende
¶ This senatour repairith with victorie
To d he sailed Riallie
And mette the ship as seith the storie
In which custaunce sit ful pitously
Nothinge ne knew he what she was newhi
She was in suche aray ne she wol not seye
Of hir estate thow she shuld die
And bryngith hir to Rome and to his wyff
He yaff hir and hir yonge sone also Man of Lawe
And with the senatour she ladde hir liff
Thus gan oure ladi bringe hir out of wo
Woful custaunce and many anothir moo
And longe time dwelled she in that place
In holi werk as euer was hir grace
¶ The senatours wiff hir Vunte was
But for al that she knew hir neuer the mor
I wol no lenger tarie as in this caas
But to kyng alla of wheche y spak of ȝor
That for his wo wepeth and siȝeth sore
I wolle Retorne and lete y woll Custaunce
Vnder the senatoures gouernaunce
¶ Kyng alla whiche hath his moder slayn
Vpon a day fell in suche Repentance
That if y shortli tellen shall and pleynli
To Rome he comyth to Resseyne his penaunce
And putt him In the popes ordinaunce
In hiȝ and lowe and Ihu crist bisouȝte
For geue þe wikked workes that he wrouȝte
¶ The fame anon thurȝe Rome toun ys born
How alla kyng is come in pilgrimage
Bi herbigoures that wente him biforn
For whiche the senatour as was þe vsage
Rode him ageyn and many of his linage
As wel to shewe his hiȝe magnificence
As to do any kyng ony Reuerence
¶ Grete cher doth this noble sanatour
To kyng alla and he to him also
Euerich tfoftof hem doth othur gret honour
And so befel that in a day or two
This senatour is to kyng alla go
And shortli if y shal not lie
Custaunces sone in his compaignie
¶ Some men wold seyn att request of Custaunce
This senatour had this Child to feste
I may not telle eủer/rey circumstaunce
Be as be may ther was he at leste
But soth it is att his moders hest
Beforn alla durynge the metes space
This Child stod lokynge in þe kynges face
¶ This alla kyng hath on the child gret wonder
And to the sanatour he seide anon
What is that fair Child that stant yonder
I not quod he bi god and seynt Iohn
A moder he hath but fader hath he non
That y of wot and shortli in astoıı̄unde
He told alla how the Child was foıı̄unde
¶ But god wote this senatour also
So vertuous alyuer in my liff
Ne saw y neuer as she is ne herde of mo
Off wordli women of maide ne of wyff
I dar wel seyn hir had leuer with a knyff
Thourȝ out hir brest thanne be awoman wikke
Ther is noman may hir brynge to þᵉ prikke
¶ Now was this Child as lik vnto Custaunce
As possible is a Creatur to be
This alla hath the visage in rememburaunce
Off dame Custaunce and there on mused he
Ief that the Childes wer ouȝt she
That is his wiff and priuili he siȝt
And sped him fro the table al that he miȝt
¶ 9fay thouȝte he fantome is in myn hed
I ouȝte to deme of skilfull Iugement
That in salt see my wyff is ded
And aftirward he made his argument
What wot y ȝif Crist / hath hedir sent
My wiff bi see as wel as he hir sent
To my Contre fro thennes that she went
¶ And aftir noon hom with the senatour
Gooth alla for to seen this wounder chaunce
This senatour doth alle gret honour
And hastli he sente aftir Custaunce
But trusteth wel hir liste not to daunce
Whanne she wist wher fore was þᵉ sonde
Vnnethe vpon hir feet might she stonde
¶ Whanne alla kyng saw his wif fair he hir grette And wepte thatMan of Lawe
And wepte that it was routhe for to see
For he att firste loke that he on hir sette
He knew verili that it was she
And forsorwe as dombe stant as atree
For so was hir herte shette in here distresse
Whanne she Remembred his vnkyndenesse
¶ Twies she swoned in his owen siȝt
He wepte and excused him pitousli
Now god qd he and his halwes bryȝt
So wisli on my soule haue merci
That of your harm gilteles am y
As is Maurice my sone so lik your face
Elles the fend me fecche out of this place
¶ Longe was þe sobbynge and the bitter peyne
Or that hir woofull herte myȝt acese
Grete was the pite for to here hem pleyne
Thurwȝ wheche pleyntes gan hir sorwe encrese
I pray yow my sorwes now relese
I may not telle hir wo til to morwe
I am so sori for to speke of sorwe
¶ But finalli whanne þe sothe is wist
That alla gilteles was Ro of hir wo
I trowe an C times ben thei kist
And suche blesse is ther betwix hem two
That saue the Ioye that lastith euer mo
Ther is non lik that ony Creatur
Hath seyn or shal while the world shal endur
¶ Tho preieth she hir husbond mekeli
In reluynge of ony pitous peyne
That he wil praye hir fader speciali
That of his mageset he wolde encline
To vouche saff some day with him to dyne
She preieth him
Vn to hir fader no for to seye
¶ Some men how that the child maurice
Doth this the emꝑper/parour
But alla kyng I gesse was not so nice
To him that honour
As he that is of Cristen men the flour
Sente any Child but it is best to deme
He wente him self ⁊and so it may well seme
¶ This emꝑper/parour hath graunted gentilly
To come to dyne as he him bisouȝt
And well redi ther he loked bisili
Vp on this Child and on his douȝter thouȝt
Alla goth to his in as him ouȝte
Arayed for the feste meny wise
As fer forth as Connynge may suffice
¶ The morwe cōmm and alla gan him dresse
And eke his wyff the emꝑper/parour to mete
And forth thei riden in Ioye and gladnesse
And whanne she sigh hir fadir in þe strete
She liȝt adouna doun and falleth him to fete
Fader qd she ȝoure yonge Child Custaunce
Is now ful Clene out of your Rememburaunce
¶ I am your douȝtir Custance qd she
That whilome ye haue sente vn to surrie
Hit am y fader that in þe salte see
Was putt allone and dampned for to die
Now gode fader mʳc y yow crie
Sende me nomor vn to non hethennesse
But thanke my lord of his kyndenesse
¶ Who can the pitous Ioye tellen all
Betwyx hem alle iij sith they ben thus ymet
But this of my tale make an ende y shal
The day gost y woll no lenger lette
These glad dyner they hem sette
In Ioye and blisse mete I lete hem dwelle
A thousand mor thanne I can telle
¶ The child was sith Emꝑper/parour
Made by
To cristes chirche he hath doıı̄un gret honour
But I lette al this passe bi
Off custaunce is my tale
In olde men fynde
Maurices lif The ꝓprolog of yᵉ Squyer
This kyng alla whanne he his time say
With his Custaunce his holi wiff so swete
To Engelond is Come the Ryȝte way
Where as the thei leue in Ioie and in quiete
But litil Ioye hit lastith y ȝow hete
Ioye of this world for tyme woll not abide
Fro day to nyȝt it Chaunged as the tide
¶ Who lyued euer in suche delite aday
That him ne meued eithur conscience
Or Ire or talent or somkynnes affray
Enuye or pride or passioıı̄un or offence
I seye but for to ende this sentence
That litil while in Ioye or in plesaunce
Lasteth the blis of alla and of custaunce
¶ For deth that taketh of high and lowe his Rente
Whanne passed is ayer as y gesse
Out of this world this kyng alla he hente
For whom Custaunce hath ful grete heuenesse
Now late vs pray þat god his soule blesse
And dame Custaunce finali to seye
Toward the town of Rome she goth hir weye
¶ To Rome is come this holi Creatur
And fyndeth hir frendes hole ⁊and sounde
Now is she scaped al hir aduentur
And whanne she had hir fader yfounde
Doun on hir knes Falleth she to grounde
Wepynge for tendirnesse in herte blithe
She heried Crist an C thousand sithe
¶ In vertue and holnesse and almess dede
They lyuen alle and neuer asonder wente
Til deth dꝑper/parte hem this liff thei ledde
And farith now welle my tale is at an ende
That ihu Crist now of his myȝt may sende
Ioye aftur woo gouerne his grace
And kepe vs alle that ben this place

div.l: (base) This was a thrifty tale for the nones
(base) Sire parissche prest quod he for goddes boones
(base) Telle vs a tale as was thi forward yore
(base) I se wel that ye lerned men in loore
(base) Can moche good by goddes dignete
(base) The persoun him answerde benedicite
(base) What eyleth the man so synfully to swere /
(base) Oure ost answerde O Ianekyn be ye there
(base) I smelle a lollere in the wynd quod he
(base) How goode men quod oure host herkeneth me
(base) Abydeth for goddes digne passioun
(base) For we schal han a predicacioun
(base) Though ye stinte on þis grene her a down
(base) This lollere heere wil prechen vs som what
(base) Nay by my fader soule that schal he nat
(base) Seyde the Esquier heer schal he nat preche

(base) Or springen Cokkel in oure clene corn

(base) That I schal waken al this compaignie
(base) But it schal not ben of philosophie
(base) Ne of Arte ne of Astrologi
(base) Ne Phislyas ne termes queinte of lawe

(base) AT Sarray in the land of Tartarye
(base) Ther dwelte a kyng that werreyed Russye
(base) Thurgh which ther deyde many a doghty man
(base) This noble kyng was clepid Kambyuskan

(base) That ther nas nowher in no Regioun

(base) Pietous and Iust and eueremoore yliche

div.l: (base) Sooth of his word benigne and honurable
(base) Of his corage as any Centre stable
(base) Yong fressh and strong in armes desirous
(base) As any Bachiler of al his hous
(base) A fair persone he was and fortunat
(base) And kepte alwey so wel Roial estat
(base) That ther nas no wher swich another man
(base) This noble kyng this Tartre Cambyuskan
(base) Hadde two sones on Elfeta his wyf
(base) Of whiche the eldeste highte Algarsyf
(base) That oother sone was clepid Cambalo
(base) A doghter hadde this worthy kyng also
(base) That yongest was and highte Canacee
(base) But for to telle yow al hir beautee
(base) It lyth nat in my tonge nyn my konnyng
(base) I dar nat vndertake so heigh a thyng
(base) Myn englyssh eek is insufficient
(base) It moste been a Rethor excellent
(base) That koude his colours longyng for that Art
(base) If he sholde hire discryuen euery part
(base) I am noon swich I moot speke as I kan
(base) And so bifel that whan this Kambyuskan
(base) Hath twenty wynter born his dyademe
(base) As he was wont fro yeer to yeer I deme
(base) He leet the feste of his Natiuitee
(base) Don crien thurgh out Sarray his Citee
(base) The laste Idus of March after the yeer
(base) Phebus the sonne ful iolyf was and cleer

div.l: (base) With dyademe ful hye in his paleys
(base) And halt his feste solempne and so riche

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibeus

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and
riche bigat vp on his wif that called was Prudence a
doghter which that called was Sophie

(base) vp on a day bifel that
he for his desport is went in to the feeldes hym to pleye

(base) his
wif and eek his doghter hath he laft inwith his hous of which
the dores weren faste yshette
(base) thre of his olde foos han it espied and setten laddres to the walles of his hous and by wyndowes ben entred

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in fyue sondry places

(base) this is to seyn
in hir feet in hir handes in hir erys in hir nose and in hir
mouth and leften hire for deed and wenten awey

(base) Whan Melibeus retourned was in to his hous and seigh al this meschief he
lyk a mad man rentynge his clothes gan to wepe and crye

(base) Prudence his wyf as ferforth as she dorste bisoughte hym of
his wepyng for to stynte

(base) but nat for thy he gan to crye and
wepen euere lenger the moore

(base) This noble wif Prudence
remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that
cleped is the remedie of loue wher as he seith

(base) he is a fool
that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hir child
til she haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn tyme

(base) and thanne
shal man doon his diligence with amyable wordes hire to reconforte and preye hire of hir wepyng for to stynte

(base) for which
reson this noble wyf Prudence suffred hir housbonde for to
wepe and crye as for a certeyn space

(base) and whan she say hir
tyme she seyde hym in this wise Allas my lord quod she
why make ye your self for to be lyk a fool
(base) for sothe it aperteneth nat to a wys man to maken swich a sorwe

(base) yowre
doghter with the grace of god shal warisshe and escape

div.l: BE þat the maunciple had his tale endid
The sonne froþe south lyne was descendid
So lowȝ that he was not to my siȝt
Degrees ix ⁊and xxᵗⁱ as of hiȝt
X of þe Clok it was þo as I gesse
For xj fote and litil more or lesse
My schadwe was at þilke tyme as þere
Off siche fete as my length partid were
In vj fete equalle off proporcioun
Ther with þe mones exaltacioıı̄un
Imene libra alwey gan ascende
As we weren entrynge at a þroppis eende The Persoıı̄un
For whiche oure ost as he was wont to gye
As in þis caas oure ioly companye
Seide in this wise lordyngꝭes eủer/reychoıı̄un
Now lakkith vs no tales mo þan oon
Fulfillid is my sentence and my decre
I trow that we haue herd of eủer/rey degre
Almost fulfillid is alle myn ordinaunce
I pray to god so ȝeue him riȝt good chaunce
Þat tellith to vs this tale lustely
Sir preest quod he art þᵘ a vicori
Or art þou a ꝑper/parsoun seysoþ bi thy fey
Be what þou be ne breke þou not our pley
For eủer/rey man saue þou hath told his tale
Vnbokle ⁊and schewe us what is in þy male
For truly me þenkith bi þi chere
Þou schuldist knyt vp wel a greet matere
Telle vs afable anon for Cokkis bones
Þis ꝑper/parsoun answerde all at ones
Þou getist fable non told for me
For poul that writith vn to tymothe
Repreueþ hem þat weyuen soþfastnesse
And tellen fables / ⁊and suche wrechidnesse
Whi schulde I sowen draff out of my fist
Whane y may sowen whete if þat me list
For whiche I seye if ȝow list to here
Moralite ⁊and vertuous matere
And þane þat ȝe wollen yeue me audience
I wol fayn at cristis reuerence
Do ȝow plesaunce leueful as y can
But triste ȝe wel I am a soþern man
I can not geste rom ram ruf bi litt̉er/ree
Ne god wote ryme holde I but littil better
And þerfore if yow lyste y woll not glose
I wol ȝou telle amery tale in prose
To knytte vp al this feste and make an ende
And ihu for his gᵃce so witte me sende
To schewe ȝow þe wey in þis viage
Of þilke ꝑper/parfiȝt glorious pilgrymage
Þat hiȝte ierlm celestial
And if ȝe fuchesauf anon I schall
Bigynne vp my tale for whiche y pᵃy
Telle ȝoure avise I can no bettir sey
But neþeles þis meditacioun
I putt it ay vndir correccioun
Of clerkis / for y am not textuel
I take but þe sentence triste ȝe wel
Þerfore I make a protestacioun
Þat I wol stonde to correccioun .
Vp on this word we han assentid sone
For as it semed it was for to done
To enden in sum vertuous sentence
And for to ȝeue space and audience
And bede oure ost he schulde do hy seye
Þat alle we to tellen his tale hīm preye
Oure ost hadde þe wordis for vs alle
Sir preest quod he now fair yow befalle
Sey what ȝow list and wewe wol gladly here
And with þat word he seide in þis maner
Telle ȝe quod he ȝoure meditacioun
But haste ȝe ȝow þe sıı̄unne wol go doun
Beþ fructuous ⁊and þat in litil space
And to do wel god sende ȝow his gᵃce Amen
Heere endiþ þe persoıı̄uns prolog and bignniþ his tal
